example: The Milky Way is just one of billions of galaxies in the universe.
A galaxy collision can trigger the formation of new stars.
Ongoing observations at the observatory track changes in star density.
Scientists use the observatory to study distant galaxies and their collisions.
Our Sun is a medium-sized star located in the Milky Way galaxy.
High star density in galaxy centers often leads to more frequent collisions.
Molten rock from volcanic eruptions can affect the Earth's climate.
Water molecules in the stratosphere can influence greenhouse effects.
The circulatory current of gases in stars generates magnetic fields.
Magnetic fields are often generated by electric currents in molten cores.
Certain minerals can magnetize when exposed to strong magnetic fields.
Meteorites can provide valuable clues about the early solar system.
Asteroids occasionally crash into planets, causing massive bombardment.
The Moon's surface shows signs of meteorite bombardment over billions of years.
Meteors burn up in the Earth's atmosphere, creating streaks of light.
Prolonged exposure to solar radiation can damage spacecraft electronics.
Scientists speculate that galaxy collisions may trigger star formation.
The new data jibes with earlier theories about galaxy evolution.
Astronomers observe different galaxies from each hemisphere on Earth.
Frost on meteorites can provide insights into space temperatures.
Volcanic eruptions can temporarily increase crop yields due to nutrient-rich ash.
Ancient almanacs recorded variations in star positions over time.
Variations in a star's brightness can indicate the presence of orbiting planets.
A dim star in the galaxy might be a candidate for hosting exoplanets.
Volcanic activity on other planets can be detected by atmospheric gas variations.
A massive volcanic eruption can release gases that affect the stratosphere.
Particles from volcanic eruptions can reach the stratosphere and affect climate.
Greenhouse gases in the atmosphere trap heat, warming the planet.
Incidentally, that asteroid's path closely matches one recorded in an ancient almanac.
Meteors crash into the Earth's atmosphere almost every day.
Cosmic rays pass through the Earth's atmosphere and reach the surface.
The theory about galaxy collisions makes sense based on recent observations.
Let me run the new galaxy collision theory by my astronomy professor.
Earth's magnetic field protects us from harmful solar radiation.
Let's back up and review the basics of star formation before discussing galaxy collisions.
This new telescope data should shed light on how galaxies evolve.
The scientist put forward a new theory about how magnetic fields form in galaxies.
